sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 2
sentence.feature: Dataset 1. Subject-verb-object (SVO)
sentence.text: A boi lobi a umapikin.
sentence.gloss: The boy loves the girl.

sentence.feature: Dataset 2. Possessum-possessor

sentence.gloss: the chief of the Aukaners

sentence.gloss: my mother's umbrella

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 8
sentence.feature: Dataset 3. Modifying adjective precedes noun
sentence.text: wan moi pikin grun wan
sentence.gloss: a pretty little green one

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn, Adrienne. 1996. On identifying instances of grammaticalization in creole languages. In Baker, Philip and Syea, Anand (eds.), Changing meanings, changing functions: Papers related to grammaticalization in contact languages, 29-46. London: University of Westminster Press.
sentence.feature: Dataset 4. Prepositions
sentence.text: Mi de na mi mama oso.
sentence.gloss: I’m at my mother’s house.

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn, Adrienne. 1996. On identifying instances of grammaticalization in creole languages. In Baker, Philip and Syea, Anand (eds.), Changing meanings, changing functions: Papers related to grammaticalization in contact languages, 29-46. London: University of Westminster Press.
sentence.feature: Dataset 4. Prepositions
sentence.text: A bedi de na ini a kamra.
sentence.gloss: The bed is in the room.

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn, Adrienne. 1996. On identifying instances of grammaticalization in creole languages. In Baker, Philip and Syea, Anand (eds.), Changing meanings, changing functions: Papers related to grammaticalization in contact languages, 29-46. London: University of Westminster Press. Example 10
sentence.feature: Dataset 4. Prepositions

sentence.gloss: with some friends of mine

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn, Adrienne. 1996. On identifying instances of grammaticalization in creole languages. In Baker, Philip and Syea, Anand (eds.), Changing meanings, changing functions: Papers related to grammaticalization in contact languages, 29-46. London: University of Westminster Press. Example 12

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn, Adrienne. 1996. On identifying instances of grammaticalization in creole languages. In Baker, Philip and Syea, Anand (eds.), Changing meanings, changing functions: Papers related to grammaticalization in contact languages, 29-46. London: University of Westminster Press. Example 14
sentence.feature: Dataset 4. Prepositions
sentence.text: Mi e go na mi mama oso.
sentence.gloss: I’m going to my mother’s house.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 18
sentence.feature: Dataset 5. Demonstrative word follows noun

sentence.gloss: that thing

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 17
sentence.feature: Dataset 5. Demonstrative word precedes noun

sentence.gloss: this week

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 21
sentence.feature: Dataset 7. Relative clause follows noun
sentence.text: a man di gi mi a papira
sentence.gloss: the man who gave me the paper

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 25
sentence.feature: Dataset 8. Degree word follows adjective
sentence.text: A liba disi bradi tumsi fu swen abra.
sentence.gloss: This river is too broad to swim across.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 27
sentence.feature: Dataset 8. Degree word follows adjective
sentence.text: A oloisi disi diri moro a dati.
sentence.gloss: This watch is more expensive than that one.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 24
sentence.feature: Dataset 8. Degree word precedes adjective
sentence.text: A oloisi disi moro diri.
sentence.gloss: This watch is more expensive.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 29
sentence.feature: Dataset 8. Degree word precedes adjective
sentence.text: A watra de bun faya.
sentence.gloss: The water is very hot.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 31
sentence.feature: Dataset 9. Definite article is preposed
sentence.text: Dati na a triki fu en.
sentence.gloss: That’s his trick.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 33
sentence.feature: Dataset 10. Indefinite article is preposed
sentence.text: wan tori fu Anansi
sentence.gloss: a story about Anansi

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 35
sentence.feature: Dataset 11. Adverb – verb – object
sentence.text: Fa ai kon dati alaten yu e kon lati na wroko.
sentence.gloss: How is it that you always come late to work?

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 36
sentence.feature: Dataset 11. Verb – object – adverb
sentence.text: Mi bari en nofrotron fu no waka nanga den boi dati.
sentence.gloss: I warned him often not to hang around with those boys.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 39
sentence.feature: Dataset 12. Interrogative phrase initial
sentence.text: San yu tyari kon gi mi?
sentence.gloss: What did you bring for me?

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 41
sentence.feature: Dataset 13. No gender distinctions
sentence.text: A de bun
sentence.gloss: He/She/It is good/well.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 43
sentence.feature: Dataset 13. No gender distinctions
sentence.text: Na en teki a buku.
sentence.gloss: It’s HER/HIM that took the book.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1984. A sketch of Sranan Tongo. In Pet, Willem (ed.), Papers on Sranan Tongo, 8-123. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. Example 45
sentence.feature: Dataset 15. Inclusive and exclusive differentiated
sentence.text: Mi heri famiri kon na a friyari-oso.
sentence.gloss: My whole family came to the birthday party.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 45
sentence.feature: Dataset 16. Syncretism between 1st and 2nd person
sentence.text: Mi heri famiri kon na a friyari-oso.
sentence.gloss: My whole family came to the birthday party.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 47
sentence.feature: Dataset 19. Interrogative pronouns: Two compound expressions
sentence.text: Suma e kon dape de?
sentence.gloss: Who is coming there?

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 49
sentence.feature: Dataset 19. Interrogative pronouns: Two compound expressions
sentence.text: Pe smoko de, faya de.
sentence.gloss: Where there is smoke, there's fire.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 51
sentence.feature: Dataset 19. Interrogative pronouns: Two compound expressions
sentence.text: So Fine, fa yu e tan?
sentence.gloss: So Fina, how are you?

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 53
sentence.feature: Dataset 21. Generic-noun-based indefinites
sentence.text: Wan sma e waka ini a strati.
sentence.gloss: Someone walks in the street.

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn, Adrienne. 2002. The structure of the Surinamese Creoles. In Carlin, Eithne B. and Arends, Jacques (eds.), Atlas of the Languages of Suriname, 153-182. Leiden: KITLV Press. Example 55
sentence.feature: Dataset 22. Variable plural marking of human or inanimate nouns
sentence.text: den oso
sentence.gloss: the houses

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn, Adrienne. 2002. The structure of the Surinamese Creoles. In Carlin, Eithne B. and Arends, Jacques (eds.), Atlas of the Languages of Suriname, 153-182. Leiden: KITLV Press. Example 55
sentence.feature: Dataset 23. Plural word preceding the noun
sentence.text: den oso
sentence.gloss: the houses

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn, Adrienne. 2002. The structure of the Surinamese Creoles. In Carlin, Eithne B. and Arends, Jacques (eds.), Atlas of the Languages of Suriname, 153-182. Leiden: KITLV Press. Example 57
sentence.feature: Dataset 25. Identity between nominal plural marker and third-person-plural pronoun
sentence.text: Den meki tumsi opo-opo.
sentence.gloss: They made a big fuss.

sentence.source: Apics. Smith, Norval S.H. 2003. New Evidence from the Past: To Epenthesize or Not to Epenthesize? That is the tags['question']. In Plag, Ingo (ed.), Phonology and Morphology of Creole Languages, 91-107. Tübingen: Niemeyer. Braun, Maria. 2009. Word-formation and creolisation. The Case of Early Sranan. Tübingen: Niemeyer. Example 59
sentence.feature: Dataset 26. Functions of reduplication: attenuating and word-class-changing function
sentence.text: a oso de férfi-férfi
sentence.gloss: he house is (in a) painted (state).

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 61
sentence.feature: Dataset 27. Antidual of paired body-part terms: no antidual
sentence.text: Esde mi drai mi futu.
sentence.gloss: Yesterday I twisted my foot.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 63
sentence.feature: Dataset 28. Definite article distinct from demonstratives
sentence.text: Ma dan fa a sani dati du kon dan eigenlijk dan.
sentence.gloss: But how did that actually happen?

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 65
sentence.feature: Dataset 29. Indefinite article identical to numeral 'one'
sentence.text: No wan sma ben bai den nyanyan.
sentence.gloss: Not one person bought them.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 67
sentence.feature: Dataset 29. Indefinite article identical to numeral 'one'
sentence.text: Nanga den sma disi wi o abi wan taki-makandra.
sentence.gloss: We will have a conversation with these people.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 69
sentence.feature: Dataset 31. Co-occurrence of demonstrative and definite article
sentence.text: A man dati kon dri leisi dya.
sentence.gloss: That man came here three times.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford transcripts. Example 70
sentence.feature: Dataset 32. Pronominal and adnominal demonstratives: same forms
sentence.text: A man disi sabi a tori.
sentence.gloss: This guy knows the story.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford transcripts. Example 72
sentence.feature: Dataset 32. Pronominal and adnominal demonstratives: same forms
sentence.text: Dati meki mi no ben kisi brede a skoro.
sentence.gloss: That’s why I didn’t get bread in school.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford transcripts. Example 74
sentence.feature: Dataset 33. Distance contrasts in demonstratives: two-way contrast
sentence.text: a man disi
sentence.gloss: this man

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 76
sentence.feature: Dataset 35. Ordinal numerals
sentence.text: fosi
sentence.gloss: first

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 78
sentence.feature: Dataset 35. Ordinal numerals
sentence.text: di fu feifi
sentence.gloss: fifth

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 79
sentence.feature: Dataset 37. Marking of pronominal possessors: preceding word
sentence.text: A uma siki moro en sisa.
sentence.gloss: The woman’s more ill than her sister.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 81
sentence.feature: Dataset 37. Marking of pronominal possessors: preceding word
sentence.text: O bigi yu futu de?
sentence.gloss: How big is your foot?

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 83
sentence.feature: Dataset 37. Marking of pronominal possessors: adpositional phrase following the possessum
sentence.text: Den tu pikin fu mi lobi fu nyan bami.
sentence.gloss: My two children love to eat bami.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 6
sentence.feature: Dataset 38. Marking of possessor noun phrases: adpositional or case marking of possessor
sentence.text: a buba fu a tigri
sentence.gloss: the tiger’s pelt

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 86
sentence.feature: Dataset 38. Marking of possessor noun phrases: adpositional or case marking of possessor
sentence.text: Ma fa a pikin fu Oom N du dede dan?
sentence.gloss: But how did Uncle N’s child actually die, then?

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 88
sentence.feature: Dataset 38. Marking of possessor noun phrases: no marking
sentence.text: Ma yu no kan kibri granmama koso.
sentence.gloss: But you can’t hide grandma's coughing.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 90
sentence.feature: Dataset 39. Identical to dependent pronominal possessor
sentence.text: A oto na fu en.
sentence.gloss: The car is his.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 91
sentence.feature: Dataset 41. Comparative adjective marking: adjective is marked
sentence.text: John de moro bigi leki Peter.
sentence.gloss: John is taller than Peter.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 92
sentence.feature: Dataset 42. Comparative standard marking: secondary surpass marking
sentence.text: John bigi moro Peter.
sentence.gloss: John’s bigger than Peter.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 94
sentence.feature: Dataset 42. Comparative standard marking: secondary surpass marking
sentence.text: John moro bigi moro Peter.
sentence.gloss: John is taller than Peter.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 96
sentence.feature: Dataset 42. Comparative standard marking: particle marking
sentence.text: Kofi bigi moro leki Kwaku.
sentence.gloss: Kofi is bigger than Kwaku

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Creoles in the context of contact linguistics. In Gilbert, Glenn (ed.), Pidgin and creole linguistics in the 21st century, 287-354. New York: Peter Lang. Example 102
sentence.feature: Dataset 44. Internal order of tense, aspect, and mood markers: Mood-Tense-Aspect
sentence.text: Nownow de Tanti M. sa ben e ferteri stori efu a ben de na libi ete.
sentence.gloss: Aunt M would have been telling stories right now if she were still alive.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Creoles in the context of contact linguistics. In Gilbert, Glenn (ed.), Pidgin and creole linguistics in the 21st century, 287-354. New York: Peter Lang. Example 100
sentence.feature: Dataset 44. Internal order of tense, aspect, and mood markers: Tense-Mood-Aspect
sentence.text: Efu John ben de dya, a ben sa e sribi now.
sentence.gloss: If John were here, he would be sleeping now.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 103
sentence.feature: Dataset 45. Tightness of the link between the past marker and the verb: particle, only grammatical markers can intervene
sentence.text: Te prani aleisi ten, mi ben e gwe go prani aleisi.
sentence.gloss: When it was time to plant rice, I went to plant rice.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 105
sentence.feature: Dataset 46. Tightness of the link between the progressive marker and the verb: particle, nothing can intervene
sentence.text: Ma yu no e man onthou ala den tori so moro.
sentence.gloss: But you can't remember all the stories anymore.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 68
sentence.feature: Dataset 30. Bare singular noun phrase in languages with definite article
sentence.text: Fowru e singi, dagu e bari.
sentence.gloss: Birds sing, dogs bark

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 107
sentence.feature: Dataset 47. Uses of the progressive marker: progressive, habitual, and current state
sentence.text: Den man e pina, yungu.
sentence.gloss: Those people are suffering, man.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 109
sentence.feature: Dataset 47. Uses of the progressive marker: progressive, habitual, and current state
sentence.text: Den e afrontu den tongo, tog.
sentence.gloss: They turn their backs on their language, right.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 111
sentence.feature: Dataset 47. Uses of the progressive marker: progressive, habitual, and current state
sentence.text: Efu pikinso wan druppel nomo kisi yu skin, yu skin e bron.
sentence.gloss: If even so much as a drop touches your skin, it burns.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 109
sentence.feature: Dataset 48. Uses of the habitual marker: habitual, progressive, and current state
sentence.text: Den e afrontu den tongo, tog.
sentence.gloss: They turn their backs on their language, right.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 112
sentence.feature: Dataset 48. Uses of the habitual marker: habitual, progressive, and current state
sentence.text: Den ben lafu unu taki unu no ben gwenti si trein.
sentence.gloss: They laughed at us saying that we weren’t used to seeing trains.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 117
sentence.feature: Dataset 48. Uses of the habitual marker: habitual, progressive, and current state
sentence.text: A man wani taki den kaw musu go pupe.
sentence.gloss: The man wanted the cows to relieve themselves.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 119
sentence.feature: Dataset 48. Uses of the habitual marker: habitual, progressive, and current state
sentence.text: Ma yu no musu du den sani dati.
sentence.gloss: But you mustn’t do those things.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 113
sentence.feature: Dataset 49. Mixed aspectual-temporal system
sentence.text: Esde di mi kon na oso a ben e skrifi wan brifi.
sentence.gloss: Yesterday when I came to the house, he was writing a letter.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 115
sentence.feature: Dataset 49. Mixed aspectual-temporal system
sentence.text: A e skrifi wan brifi.
sentence.gloss: She’s writing a letter.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 118
sentence.feature: Dataset 50. Same TAM marking in negated clauses
sentence.text: Efu yu no wroko, dan you no o nyan, tog.
sentence.gloss: If you don’t work, then you won’t eat, right?

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 120
sentence.feature: Dataset 50. Same TAM marking in negated clauses
sentence.text: A musu de taki na den pikin nyan a kuku.
sentence.gloss: It must be the case that it was the children who ate the cake.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 122
sentence.feature: Dataset 51. Stative verbs with present reference and dynamic verbs with past perfective reference are both unmarked
sentence.text: A kamra kowru bikaa me opo a fensre.
sentence.gloss: The room is cold because I opened the window.

sentence.source: Apics. Seuren, Pieter. 1981. Tense and aspect in Sranan. Linguistics 19. 1043-1076. Example 124
sentence.feature: Dataset 52. Inchoative expressed by progressive marker
sentence.text: A manya e lepi.
sentence.gloss: The mango is getting ripe.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 126
sentence.feature: Dataset 53. Aspect change in verb chains is not possible
sentence.text: A e waka na foto e seri krosi.
sentence.gloss: He walks around in town selling clothes.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 127
sentence.feature: Dataset 55. Ability verb also expresses epistemic possibility
sentence.text: Den kan e wakti unu na oso.
sentence.gloss: They may be awaiting us at home.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 129
sentence.feature: Dataset 55. Ability verb also expresses epistemic possibility
sentence.text: Mi kan go na dansi bikasi mi abi moni.
sentence.gloss: I can go to the dance because I have money.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 131
sentence.feature: Dataset 56. The prohibitive: normal imperative construction and normal negator
sentence.text: Unu no naki en!
sentence.gloss: Don’t you guys hit it!

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 133
sentence.feature: Dataset 56. The prohibitive: normal imperative construction and normal negator
sentence.text: Naki en!
sentence.gloss: Hit it!

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 135
sentence.feature: Dataset 57. No marking of patient NPs
sentence.text: Den nyan ala den gansi!
sentence.gloss: They ate all the geese.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 136
sentence.feature: Dataset 58. Alignment of case marking of full noun phrases: neutral alignment
sentence.text: Den agu nyan den beest?
sentence.gloss: The pigs ate the geese?

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 138
sentence.feature: Dataset 59. Alignment of case marking of personal pronouns: accusative alignment
sentence.text: A kon mangri.
sentence.gloss: He’s gotten skinny.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 140
sentence.feature: Dataset 59. Alignment of case marking of personal pronouns: accusative alignment
sentence.text: En na mi mati.
sentence.gloss: He’s my friend.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 142
sentence.feature: Dataset 59. Alignment of case marking of personal pronouns: accusative alignment
sentence.text: Kande en srefi e kon na foto bori na agu gi mi.
sentence.gloss: Perhaps he himself comes to the city to cook the pig for me.

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn and Adrienne and Muysken, Pieter and Verrips, Maaike. 1999. Double-object constructions in the creole languages: development and acquisition. In DeGraff, Michel (ed.), Language creation and language change: Creolization, diachrony and development, 329-373. Cambridge, MA: MIT Press. Example 144
sentence.feature: Dataset 60. Ditransitive constructions with 'give': double-object construction
sentence.text: Granmama gi den pikin tori fa a ben de fosten.
sentence.gloss: Grandmother told the children stories about how it was in the old days.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 146
sentence.feature: Dataset 61. Order of recipient and theme in ditransitive constructions: Subject – verb – recipient – theme
sentence.text: A trawan gi a boi, gi a tra boi feifi, a vijfhonderd.
sentence.gloss: The other one gave the boy, gave the boy five, the five hundred.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 148
sentence.feature: Dataset 61. Order of recipient and theme in ditransitive constructions: Subject – verb – recipient – theme
sentence.text: Dus den musu gi mi furu watra fu mi dringi.
sentence.gloss: So they need to give me a lot of water to drink.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 149
sentence.feature: Dataset 62. Expression of pronominal subjects: Obligatory pronoun words
sentence.text: Mi no wani taki nanga yu.
sentence.gloss: I don’t want to talk to you.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 151
sentence.feature: Dataset 63. Expletive subject in ‘seem’ constructions: an expletive subject is used
sentence.text: Ma a gersi taki den kuli wani teki a kondre now op yungu.
sentence.gloss: But it seems that the Hindustanis want to take over the country now, man

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 154
sentence.feature: Dataset 64. Expletive subject of existential verb: an expletive subject is not used
sentence.text: Merki no de srefisrefi a foto.
sentence.gloss: There isn’t any milk at all in town.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 156
sentence.feature: Dataset 65. Raining constructions: rain falls
sentence.text: Dan mi taki ai, a no pikinso alen fadon.
sentence.gloss: Then I said, ‘well, it rained a lot.' (Lit. 'it wasn't just a little rain that fell')

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 159
sentence.feature: Dataset 66. Experiencer constructions with 'headache': body-part is subject
sentence.text: Mi ede span span wan sortu fasi.
sentence.gloss: I have some sort of a headache.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 158
sentence.feature: Dataset 66. Experiencer constructions with 'headache': pain is subject
sentence.text: Ede-hati e kiri mi.
sentence.gloss: A headache is killing me.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 161
sentence.feature: Dataset 67. Experiencer constructions with 'like': experiencer is subject
sentence.text: Mi lobi pley bal.
sentence.gloss: I like to play football (soccer).

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 163
sentence.feature: Dataset 68. Experiencer is subject, 'fear' is verbal
sentence.text: A man e frede a kaaiman.
sentence.gloss: He’s afraid of the crocodile.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 165
sentence.feature: Dataset 68. Experiencer is subject, 'fear' is verbal
sentence.text: Mi frede, yu go tapu en.
sentence.gloss: I’m scared, you go and close it.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 170
sentence.feature: Dataset 69. Instrumental expressions: serial verb
sentence.text: Boi, teki a tin sensi dya go bai tabaka gi mi.
sentence.gloss: Boy, take this dime and go and get me some tobacco.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 166
sentence.feature: Dataset 69. Instrumental expressions: adposition
sentence.text: So wan leisi a naki mi nanga wan batra.
sentence.gloss: So one time she hit me with a bottle.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 168
sentence.feature: Dataset 69. Instrumental expressions: adposition
sentence.text: Dus dan so unu ben kon a foto nanga a bigi boto.
sentence.gloss: So that’s how we came to Paramaribo on the big ship.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 173
sentence.feature: Dataset 70. Comitatives and instrumentals: identity
sentence.text: Mi go nanga mi brada na foto.
sentence.gloss: I went to town with my brother.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 175
sentence.feature: Dataset 70. Comitatives and instrumentals: identity
sentence.text: A e teki den tyari gwe go, go drai miri.
sentence.gloss: He would take them along to go turn the mill.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 36
sentence.feature: Dataset 71. Noun phrase conjunction and comitative: identity
sentence.text: Mi bari en nofrotron fu no waka nanga den boi dati.
sentence.gloss: I warned him often not to hang around with those boys.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 178
sentence.feature: Dataset 71. Noun phrase conjunction and comitative: identity
sentence.text: Anansi ben prei wan triki nanga Kakalaka nanga Kafowru.
sentence.gloss: Anansi played a trick on Cockroach and Chicken.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 180
sentence.feature: Dataset 72. Nominal and verbal conjunction: differentiation
sentence.text: Yu e go na a mma dan yu o taki.
sentence.gloss: You’d go to the mother and you’d speak.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 182
sentence.feature: Dataset 73. Predicative noun phrases: invariant copula
sentence.text: Den tu sma disi na Sranansma.
sentence.gloss: These two people are Surinamese.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 41
sentence.feature: Dataset 74. Predicative adjectives: variable copula
sentence.text: A de bun.
sentence.gloss: He/She/It is good/well.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 185
sentence.feature: Dataset 74. Predicative adjectives: variable copula
sentence.text: A pikin siki.
sentence.gloss: The child is ill.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 187
sentence.feature: Dataset 74. Predicative adjectives: variable copula
sentence.text: A ma dati srefi de vol.
sentence.gloss: That mother (cow) herself is pregnant

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 189
sentence.feature: Dataset 75. Predicative locative phrases: invariant copula
sentence.text: Den pikin ben de na skoro.
sentence.gloss: The children were at school.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 191
sentence.feature: Dataset 75. Predicative locative phrases: invariant copula
sentence.text: A boi fu dya bakasey no drape moro?
sentence.gloss: The guy in the back is not there anymore?

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 183
sentence.feature: Dataset 76. Predicative noun phrases and predicative locative phrases: differentiation
sentence.text: Den tu man na skowtu.
sentence.gloss: The two men are policemen.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 190
sentence.feature: Dataset 76. Predicative noun phrases and predicative locative phrases: differentiation
sentence.text: A owru de baka a doro.
sentence.gloss: The machete is behind the door.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 193
sentence.feature: Dataset 76. Predicative noun phrases and predicative locative phrases: differentiation
sentence.text: Yu sabi Dark Shadow ben de wan frede film.
sentence.gloss: You know Dark Shadow was a scary movie.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 195
sentence.feature: Dataset 77. Predicative possession: transitive
sentence.text: Yungu, yu no abi ai fu sii?
sentence.gloss: Boy, don’t you have eyes?

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 197
sentence.feature: Dataset 77. Predicative possession: transitive
sentence.text: Te wan mama abi pikin kba, a pikin musu nyan.
sentence.gloss: When a mother has a child, the child must eat.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 199
sentence.feature: Dataset 78. Existential verb and transitive possession verb: overlap
sentence.text: Pe wan pikin nengre de, zegen nanga blesi de ini a oso dati.
sentence.gloss: Where there’s a child, there are blessings in that house.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 201
sentence.feature: Dataset 78. Existential verb and transitive possession verb: overlap
sentence.text: Yu abi furu Sumter di mi no sabi.
sentence.gloss: There are many people by the name of Sumter that I don’t know.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 209
sentence.feature: Dataset 79. Going to named places: Serial verb plus preposition
sentence.text: Dan mi post dri go na Holland.
sentence.gloss: Then I mailed three to Holland.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 207
sentence.feature: Dataset 79. Going to named places: preposition
sentence.text: A blaka man kari a ingi taki kon unu go na Kwatta pasi.
sentence.gloss: The black guy called the Indian saying let’s go to Kwatta street.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 211
sentence.feature: Dataset 80. Coming from named places: serial verb plus preposition
sentence.text: Yu yere dati Turku e suku yu, a betre yu wijk uit komoto na Holland.
sentence.gloss: You hear that the Turks are looking for you, you better get out of Holland.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 203
sentence.feature: Dataset 81. Motion-to and motion-from: overlap
sentence.text: Den pikin e go na skoro.
sentence.gloss: The children go to school.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 205
sentence.feature: Dataset 81. Motion-to and motion-from: overlap
sentence.text: Te den pranasi sma ben kmopo fu tapusei kon nanga boto.
sentence.gloss: When the people of the plantation came from upriver by boat.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 213
sentence.feature: Dataset 82. Transitive motion verbs 'push': serial verb construction plus preposition
sentence.text: Skoifi a kasi go ini a uku.
sentence.gloss: Push the cabinet into the corner.

sentence.source: Apics. Sebba, Mark. 1987. The syntax of serial verbs. An investigation into serialisation in Sranan and other languages. Amsterdam: John Benjamins. Example 215
sentence.feature: Dataset 83. Transitive motion verbs 'pull': serial verb construction plus preposition
sentence.text: Kofi hari a pikin komoto na ini a olo.
sentence.gloss: Kofi pulled the child out of the hole.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 217
sentence.feature: Dataset 84. Directional serial verb constructions with 'come' and 'go': directionals exist
sentence.text: A ben rij kon na post na mi tog, tra dei tog, tra esde.
sentence.gloss: He had come to me at the station the other day, the day before yesterday.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 219
sentence.feature: Dataset 85. 'Take' serial verb constructions: theme of the second verb, literal interpretation possible
sentence.text: Kande a man teki omeni poti ini en saka kba.
sentence.gloss: Maybe the man took a lot for his own pocket already.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 221
sentence.feature: Dataset 85. 'Take' serial verb constructions: theme of the second verb, literal interpretation impossible
sentence.text: Hey, den man, den man e teki a sani e meki grap.
sentence.gloss: Hey, they are making the joke of the matter.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 222
sentence.feature: Dataset 86. 'Give' serial verb constructions: 'give' in second position, recipient or beneficiary
sentence.text: Bori pikin supu gi ma Akuba nanga pikin Anansi.
sentence.gloss: Cook a little soup for mother Akuba and little spider.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 224
sentence.feature: Dataset 86. 'Give' serial verb constructions: 'give' in second position, recipient or beneficiary
sentence.text: No, a kil musu du wan sani gi mi ini a gare.
sentence.gloss: No, the man has to do something for me in the house.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 226
sentence.feature: Dataset 87. Reflexive constructions: compound reflexive pronoun with emphasizer
sentence.text: A ten di a kisi en srefi taki a ben musu gwe nanga a kromanti.
sentence.gloss: When he realized that, he had to go away with the spirit.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 227
sentence.feature: Dataset 88. Intensifiers and reflexive pronouns are identical
sentence.text: Mi srefi dya abi famiri mi no sabi.
sentence.gloss: I myself have relatives that I don’t know.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 229
sentence.feature: Dataset 88. Intensifiers and reflexive pronouns are identical
sentence.text: Skowtu srefi no sabi suma fufuru a wagi.
sentence.gloss: Even the police don’t know who stole the car.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 231
sentence.feature: Dataset 89. Reciprocal constructions: identical and special reciprocal construction
sentence.text: Den lobi densrefi tumsi.
sentence.gloss: They love themselves too much.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 233
sentence.feature: Dataset 90. Passive constructions: passive without verbal coding
sentence.text: Kande den suma disi ben kweki tra fasi.
sentence.gloss: Maybe these people were raised differently.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 235
sentence.feature: Dataset 90. Passive constructions: passive without verbal coding
sentence.text: A krosi e krin.
sentence.gloss: The clothes are being cleaned.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 238
sentence.feature: Dataset 92. Subject relative clauses: relative particle and gap
sentence.text: A libi di ben de a fosi nanga di fu now papa a no wan.
sentence.gloss: Life today is different from that of the days gone by.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 236
sentence.feature: Dataset 92. Subject relative clauses: relative pronoun
sentence.text: Dan den suma san e libi dyaso o abi fu teki ala a wroko.
sentence.gloss: Then the people that live here will have to do all the work.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 240
sentence.feature: Dataset 92. Subject relative clauses: zero and gap
sentence.text: Yu sabi wan boi ben de na skowtu den e kari en Oscar?
sentence.gloss: Do you know a guy named Oscar who was a police officer?

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2008. Atlantic creole syntax. In Kouwenberg, Silvia and Singler, John (eds.), The handbook of pidgin and creole studies, 19-47. Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell. Example 246
sentence.feature: Dataset 93. Object relative clauses: zero and resumptive pronoun
sentence.text: Yu sabi wan boi ben de na skowtu den e kari en Oscar?
sentence.gloss: Do you know a guy named Oscar who was a police officer?

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2008. Atlantic creole syntax. In Kouwenberg, Silvia and Singler, John (eds.), The handbook of pidgin and creole studies, 19-47. Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell. Example 241
sentence.feature: Dataset 93. Object relative clauses: relative pronoun
sentence.text: Dus dan a man kon ferstan taki na frow san a wasi.
sentence.gloss: So then the man understood that it was the woman whom he had washed.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2008. Atlantic creole syntax. In Kouwenberg, Silvia and Singler, John (eds.), The handbook of pidgin and creole studies, 19-47. Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell. Example 243
sentence.feature: Dataset 93. Object relative clauses: relative particle and gap
sentence.text: Wan bigi man ben dape di den e kari papa Mani.
sentence.gloss: An elderly man worked there whom they called papa Mani.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2008. Atlantic creole syntax. In Kouwenberg, Silvia and Singler, John (eds.), The handbook of pidgin and creole studies, 19-47. Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell. Example 319
sentence.feature: Dataset 94. Instrument relative clauses: relative particle and resumptive pronoun
sentence.text: dan a man di mi nanga en e taki...
sentence.gloss: then the man who I was talking to...

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2008. Atlantic creole syntax. In Kouwenberg, Silvia and Singler, John (eds.), The handbook of pidgin and creole studies, 19-47. Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell. Example 248
sentence.feature: Dataset 94. Instrument relative clauses: Relative pronoun with pied-piping
sentence.text: Nanga san yu koti a brede?
sentence.gloss: What did you cut the bread with?

sentence.source: Apics. Plag, Ingo. 1993. Sentential complementation in Sranan: On the formation of an English-based creole language. (Linguistische Arbeiten 300.) Tübingen: Max Niemeyer Verlag. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 250
sentence.feature: Dataset 95. Complementizer with verbs of speaking: complementizer identical to bare 'say'
sentence.text: A bonuman taigi a frow taki a musu weri wan bereketi fu kan kon betre.
sentence.gloss: The medicine man told the woman that she had to wear a chain around her waist in order to get better.

sentence.source: Apics. Plag, Ingo. 1993. Sentential complementation in Sranan: On the formation of an English-based creole language. (Linguistische Arbeiten 300.) Tübingen: Max Niemeyer Verlag. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 254
sentence.feature: Dataset 96. Complementizer with verbs of knowing: no complementizer
sentence.text: Mi bribi a man gwe na Holland volgens mi, yere.
sentence.gloss: I believe he’s gone to Holland.

sentence.source: Apics. Plag, Ingo. 1993. Sentential complementation in Sranan: On the formation of an English-based creole language. (Linguistische Arbeiten 300.) Tübingen: Max Niemeyer Verlag. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 253
sentence.feature: Dataset 96. Complementizer with verbs of knowing: complementizer identical to bare ‘say’
sentence.text: Di mi si dati a susu no e fiti mi, mi tyari en go kenki.
sentence.gloss: When I realized that the shoes didn't fit me, I went and exchanged them.

sentence.source: Apics. Plag, Ingo. 1993. Sentential complementation in Sranan: On the formation of an English-based creole language. (Linguistische Arbeiten 300.) Tübingen: Max Niemeyer Verlag. Example 117
sentence.feature: Dataset 98. Complements of 'think' and 'want': identical complementizer
sentence.text: A man wani taki den kaw musu go pupe.
sentence.gloss: The man wanted the cows to relieve themselves.

sentence.source: Apics. Plag, Ingo. 1993. Sentential complementation in Sranan: On the formation of an English-based creole language. (Linguistische Arbeiten 300.) Tübingen: Max Niemeyer Verlag. Example 257
sentence.feature: Dataset 98. Complements of 'think' and 'want': identical complementizer
sentence.text: Dati ede den no wani mi taki.
sentence.gloss: Therefore they don't want me to talk.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 259
sentence.feature: Dataset 99. Verb doubling in temporal clauses: verb doubling is not possible in temporal clauses
sentence.text: Fa un doro un bigin wroko.
sentence.gloss: As soon as we arrived, we began to work.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 261
sentence.feature: Dataset 99. Verb doubling in temporal clauses: verb doubling is not possible in temporal clauses
sentence.text: En te den man dati e kon tapu a dan, dan den e law.
sentence.gloss: And when those guys come out on the street, they go crazy.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 263
sentence.feature: Dataset 100. Negative morpheme types: negative particle
sentence.text: A diri k’farlek, yu no man bai en.
sentence.gloss: It’s terribly expensive, you can’t buy it.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 264
sentence.feature: Dataset 101. Position of standard negation: before the verb
sentence.text: Mi no feni en, mi no feni a fopper.
sentence.gloss: I haven’t found it, I haven’t found the pacifier.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 266
sentence.feature: Dataset 102. Negation and indefinite pronouns: co-occurrence with predicate negation
sentence.text: Yu no abi fu abi noti.
sentence.gloss: You don’t have to have any.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 268
sentence.feature: Dataset 103. Polar tags['question']s: final tags['question'] particle
sentence.text: Oh, ma dan a ben kan kon taki now, tog?
sentence.gloss: Oh, but then he could come and chat now, right?

sentence.source: Apic. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 270
sentence.feature: Dataset 103. Polar tags['question']s: only interrogative intonation
sentence.text: Yu no musu sabi wan fosi ten tori?
sentence.gloss: Surely you know an old time story?

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 120
sentence.feature: Dataset 104. Focusing of the noun phrase: cleft with copula before focus
sentence.text: A musu de taki na den pikin nyan a kuku.
sentence.gloss: It must be the case that it was the children who ate the cake.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 273
sentence.feature: Dataset 104. Focusing of the noun phrase: cleft with copula before focus
sentence.text: Na leriman a man de.
sentence.gloss: The man’s a TEACHER.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 275
sentence.feature: Dataset 105. Verb doubling and focus: verb fronted with a copy in the background clause
sentence.text: A musu de feti den ben feti, yu sabi.
sentence.gloss: They must have been fighting, you know.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 277
sentence.feature: Dataset 105. Verb doubling and focus: verb fronted with a copy in the background clause
sentence.text: Na kon yu e kon fu teki a moni kba?
sentence.gloss: You’ve come already to take the money?

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 280
sentence.feature: Dataset 106. Focus particle 'also': after the focused element
sentence.text: Mi tu no erken, dati meki mi e tyari Miller.
sentence.gloss: I too wasn’t acknowledged (as someone’s child), that’s why I go by the name of Miller.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 281
sentence.feature: Dataset 106. Focus particle 'also': non-adjacent following
sentence.text: Na so mi ben tyari mi srefi tu.
sentence.gloss: That’s how I, too, behaved.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 283
sentence.feature: Dataset 107. Vocative markers: optional vocative marker preceding noun
sentence.text: Gilly, kon yere.
sentence.gloss: Gilly, come hear [this].

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 285
sentence.feature: Dataset 108. Para-linguistic usages of clicks: clicks can express only affective meanings
sentence.text: Ma fosi, yu ben abi wan wan sma di o du a sani dati, ma te yu meki a tyuri now, dan a bigi sma kan teki yu gewoon dan a fon yu.
sentence.gloss: But before, you had a few people who did that, but if you made the 'sucking_sound_with_your_lips' now then the older person would just take you and give you a beating.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 291
sentence.feature: Dataset 113. 'Finger' and 'toe': differentiation
sentence.text: Fa mi broko mi finga, mi no man knopo mi empi.
sentence.gloss: Because I broke my finger, I cannot button my shirt.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 295
sentence.feature: Dataset 115. 'Hear' and 'smell': differentiation
sentence.text: Smeri a nyanyan gi mi efu a no swa.
sentence.gloss: Smell the food for me to see if it is spoiled.
